H0.text: 2Sn + 4HNO₃ → SnO₂ + 4NO₂ + H₂O demonstrates the conservation of matter, as shown by the chemical equation.

H1.text: I₂ + 5 Cl₂ + 6 H₂O → 2 HIO₃ + 10 HCl demonstrates the conservation of matter by showing that the total number of atoms of each element is the same on both sides of the equation.

H2.text: Cl + 4Na → 4NaCl demonstrates the conservation of matter by showing that the number of atoms of each element is the same on both sides of the chemical equation.

H3.text: 4P + 5HNO₃ → 5NO + 3H₃PO₄ is the chemical equation that demonstrates the conservation of matter.

A4.text: The principle implies that during a chemical reaction the total mass of the reactants is equal to the total mass of the products.

A5.text: In physics and chemistry, the law of conservation of mass or principle of mass conservation states that for any system which is closed to all incoming and outgoing transfers of matter, the mass of the system must remain constant over time.
